description: From Middle English schateren (“to scatter, dash”), an assibilated form of Middle English scateren ("to scatter"; see scatter), from Old English scaterian, from Proto-Germanic *skat- (“to smash, scatter”). Cognate with Dutch schateren (“to burst out laughing”), Low German schateren, Albanian shkatërroj (“to destroy, devastate”).  Doublet of scatter.

entries.meaning: (countable, archaic) A fragment of anything shattered.
examples: to break a glass into shatters

entries.meaning: (uncountable, slang) A form of concentrated cannabis.

verbs.description: shatter (third-person singular simple present shatters, present participle shattering, simple past and past participle shattered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To violently break something into pieces.
examples: The miners used dynamite to shatter rocks.
a high-pitched voice that could shatter glass
The old oak tree has been shattered by lightning.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To smash, or break into tiny pieces.

examples: to be shattered in intellect; to have shattered hopes, or a shattered constitution

entries.meaning: (intransitive, agriculture) Of seeds: to be dispersed upon ripening.
examples: Harvesting is done much as with alfalfa, but alsike seed is small and shatters if it is not handled carefully.
